comments.text: got dropped off here with a friend, coming from Goris, wanted to go to Tatev, even before we stopped an armenian-russian group stopped and took us to Tatev
We went to Yerevan and a taxi stopped after 5 minutes - asked only for a bus fare (2500 AMD each).
Gas station, direction Nagorno-Karabakh, Yerevan or Tatev monastery.

hitchhiked from the edge of gyumri to tbilisi over many rides, the waiting time was always very short, however many drivers will decline you a ride because they're not going all the way because they don't understand that hitchhiking is about getting many smaller rides, so you may need to explain this to them

Direction Vanadzor. We started after sunset and had a kind man driving us to Spitak in a comfortable Lexus. He called his colleagues till he found one who could drive us to Vanadzor.
Also 3 more hippie friends of us found a ride to Spitak first and Vanadzor then.
Gyumri will miss us, 25 free souls camping in the central park busking and dancing in the streets day and night :) see u in 5
Perfect place to hitchike to south, Karabakh. People are amazingly friendly
Most people stopped, but departed after explaining I wasn't paying.  Eventually got a ride all the way to Tabriz.

On both sides of the border: just walk a bit away from the taxis and start hitching (on the Iranian side you might have to explain to the drivers who stop for you what you are doing though. And make sure to mention that you don't wanna pay for the ride!)

The Khor Virap (Armenian: Խոր Վիրապ, meaning "deep pit" or "deep well") is an Armenian Apostolic Church monastery located in the Ararat plain in Armenia, near the border with Turkey, about 8 kilometres (5.0 mi) south of Artashat, Ararat Province. The monastery was host to a theological seminary and was the residence of Armenian Catholicos.
Khor Virap's notability as a monastery and pilgrimage site is attributed to the fact that Grigor Lusavorich, who later became Saint Gregory the Illuminator, w
No problem to hitch from the border south. Just walk a bit away from the waiting taxis of course.
many vehicles going to Yerevan after crossing border. Find a location where vehicle tends to slow down (such as after narrow road).
I waited just few minutes. Direction - georgian border.
Just after the bridge, I waited just few minutes. Direction - georgian border
Direction to Dilijan. Perfect place.
it is half hour walk from center, get a lift to Yerevan
along the road we can hike, even at 5pm in winter (it was getting dark) we got a lift to Dilijan
Needless to say, but from this spot it is very easy to get a ride - just as in any other place in Armenia :)
This is a bit of a no brainer really as its the only north-south road. You will not have to wait very long.
Very good spot for hitchhiking. Just walk out of Ashtarak and start hitching. I had a ride after 2 minutes from some guys that were going in the opposite direction and brought me a long way!
Place is near a small gas station, right after an intersection, and before a left turn on the main road to Ashtarak, Talin and Gyumri. Great place to hitchhike! Waiting time < 10 min.
Lusagyugh is a great spot if heading to Ejmiatsin.
An excellent spot to hitchhike in the direction of Georgia (Tbilisi). Got a ride to the border in 2 minutes.
in yerevan took a bus from the train station to visit khor virap monastery. than hitched more to the south.
Got a ride with an Iranian truck driver to Vayk, I think most cars take the other route via Goris though.
Most drivers from here go to Yerevan
Very easy to get to Dilijan (or Sevanavank).
Easy to get to Sevan. Lichk Lodge is a lovely place to stay in Lichk, cheap and such friendly owners.
Direction Yerevan, plenty of space to pull over.
Direction: Goris, Tatev, Sisian.
A lot of tourists. Sign in Latin script should be enought.

Cars ride basically only to Geghard and Garni, so if you want to hitchhike there, it's ideal.
(Hitchhiked with friend)
Lots of traffic, and the stoplights at the crossroads slow cars down, which helps. It wasn’t hard to get a ride to Sevan. Overall, a good spot.

Got dropped off here unfortunately but had my Yerevan sign. Would have probably worked without. Walk a bit till you find a good spot for yourself, there is a lot of space for cars to stop anywhere. Took me 5 minutes
Lots of traffic easy to get to Vanadzor
nice old man have stop us, two smelly hikermans, and took us with his old rusty Gazelle van to Dilijan.

Kadjaran is a small town that everyone crosses on the way from Kapan to Meghri, Iran and opposite. If you are going north, find a car going to Kapan and take the bus number 5 to the eastern end of the city, where the road intersection goes left to Yerevan. I had a young guy offering me coffee, taking me to the next village, waiting with me for the Kadjaran-Kapan bus and then finding a friend of his to drive me there.

Best spot from Meghri to north. If a local wants to take you here (Lehvaz village intersection) from Meghri, then accept! There are people leaving the village, there's space for trucks to stop. A covered bus stop against sun or rain. Also dusty blackberries in september. A spanish cyclist going south stopped for conversation and got a local white Lada stopping for me after 2 hours i was waiting :D Elders took me have lunch at their roulotte by a very twisty part of the road, then i hitchhiked wi

Very good spot if you are arriving from south (Ararat province) and you wanna skip the traffic of Yerevan on your way west - Echmiadzin, Armavir, Gyumri. You'll also skip the airport area and the need of taking buses to reach western suburbs. Mind that these western cities are industrialized, so people drive for money more than elsewhere.
I got offers to Masis until a guy took me to Hayanist.

Super spot. 4 colourful wanderers, we camped in Areni floodgate and came here at 11am brought by a friend's car to find a direct ride to Iran. After 5 minutes playing music and singing by smiley food vendors, two armenian trucks stopped for us and drove all the way to Agarak, which border i really missed since 2 years ago.
We had signs to Meghri but they were really useless, as everyone would understand we're going as much south as possible. I'm in Samuel Hostel in Agarak, Iran will see me agai

I camped in the small forest by walking uphill from the train station, crossed the road from station underpass and got a ride by an empty bus

The Sevanavank monastery in the peninsula is very touristic and gave me good money by busking down at the restaurants
Wonderful mountain road from Ttujur to Berd. A truck carrying pillars took me to his workplace then 2 men to Berd, offering to show me the fortress and ending up gifting a Holy Bible.
Got an unexpected ride to Yerevan after 5 minutes so I didn't go explore the south of Sevan lake by Vardenis and Martuni
A touristic church for busking is here uphill in Haghpat, while a covered camping spot can be provided on the left of the shop on the main road.

It took me 5 cars to get to Alaverdi and only a bit of extra waiting here so i could proof again how this country is hitchhikers-friendly. On the other side, arriving here as a guy alone from Marneuli was time-consuming so i suggest to find a direct ride from Tbilisi.
An empty, stunningly beautiful border. I crossed it in August 2022 on the way from Iran to Tbilisi and i really miss it. After a bit of walking, the guys in a shop took us to the first village.
On the main route heading south, many trucks going to Iran
Northern Bus Station is a good place to hitch rides to Sevan and Dilijan. Taxi & Marshrutka drivers might be insistent, if so then just walk a little up the road.
Great spot, can get rides to Garni or Geghard very easily and quick
A Georgian truck stop directly
alright spot to vanadzor

They made me sleep on a couch at the park café next to the railway pedestrian bridge and then i continued hitchhiking to Gyumri. I also met 2 chinese bikepackers camping at the shop after the intersection to Haghpat in the east of Alaverdi.
 These 2 gas stations have public wifi. Super kind russian guy took me to Vanadzor and had me refusing his money offer :)
Direction: Sevan. Low traffic, but people stop.
waited 20min for a ride to somewhere next to Yerevan
crossroad on the yerevan-goris road to lake sevan. low traffic, but friendly people.

Come here by metro to Shengavit or Garegin and jump on the bus 6, 51, 55 or 55w - check more direct options from the city center to Karach market on app A2B Yerevan transport. 100amd each ride.
I accepted the second offer to Artashat as it was getting dark and the guy dropped me at his market on the main road. Another guy took me to one more market+ cheap bbq restaurant (they call them bistro) where the owner spared a grilled potato lavaş with me. Stand at the crossroad where the cars accelerat

Direction: south. This is the place where a real highway out of the city finally starts. In October 2014 construction of the road was still happening and it made hitchhiking a bit harder. When the road is finished it should be easy to hitchhike here.
Tatev ride in less than 10 minutes.
Hitching on this spot at the turn-off for Sisian is good for getting rides to Yerevan or Goris/Nagorno Karabagh.
Get out of car.  Hold out Iran sign.  Get a ride to the border.  Easy.
From south of town it's alos no problem to catch a ride to the Iranian border.

Walk up north from the town of Meghri. Then start hitchhiking from there, it's a good spot! Not much traffic, a lot of space to stop. Plus it's only one road so everyone coming from Iran going to Kapan or even Yerevan will cross this point.
I got picked up instantly before I could even put my thumb up so ymmv however pretty much every car on this road is going to Gyumri
Quiet around 3/4pm, I still managed a ride south in 30 mins with a sign for Iran.
Outside of the twon it's not a problem to catch a ride in your direction.
Not a bad spot, but lots of local traffic.  Occasional drivers going longer distances.  A sign for Iran an I was picked up in half an hour.

Good spot for hitching South.  A sign for Iran had me picked up in 20 mins, but there's a lot of local traffic.  I always just try to hitch with higher end vehicles.  Lada's and such cars are almost always local, and will almost always ask you for money.
Just few meters from cab station.  Direction to Georgia.
Right after the intersection, towards the north, lots of place to stop for cars and traffic goes slow.
5 minutes and a car stopped. The driver wanted 2500 AMD each to Akhalkalaki (he went there) and 5000 AMD more (total) to Vardzia.
Direction Georgia. A lot of space to pull over.
There's a lot of taxi drivers that will tell you hitchhiking will not be successful but the people here are great.
Leaving the customs towards Armenia.
It was really good place! we've been walking along no man's land, it was nice place & good for hitchhking
lovely armenian customs asked cars to take us. although the two border posts are quite far, count 30 mins walking on the no man\\'s land.
Yes, it´s great spot, but there´s almost anybody going so far to Stepanakert. But mashrutkas are having rest here, so you can ask drivers
yerevan-karabakh road goes above from the town. this is a great spot to get a ride to stepanakert.

Road to Dogubayazit

And a wonderfull scennery!

Ask in the city if someone can bring you there, people are friendly and should help you, so you won't walk too much in this big city.

Theoretically a good spot to Gyumri and Ashtarak I think. Unfortunately I realized way to late inti the ride that this is not a group of friends but a shared taxi. It did not say taxi anywhere. Driver acted like people I hitched with, so I assumed no need to make the money issue clear. You should…. Anyway in the end it was 1.500 Dram so 3,40€ roughly.

Arriving here from central Armenia is easy and fun - check the spot in Areni. Leaving to anywhere up north can take long time! I did it 2 years ago from Iran and got stuck in Lehvaz village of Meghri, where a farmer gave me a couch and a truck took me to Kapan in the morning. I did it again during a long exploration of the country this week and got a ride to Meghri after 2 hours, waited 2 hours in the evening, camped and waited 6 hours in the morning. I also walked up to Lehvaz, it is a better s
When heading south from Yerevan the minibus turns around here, you can get out and hitch under the bridge to avoid the sun, there’s lots of room for cars to pull over
Maybe it was because it was lunchtime, but I struggled here for longer than I should have.  Decent spot though if you get lucky.
As usual: walk to the edge of town and start hitchhing. Maybe you get invited to some vodkas on the way :-)
Dont take this road around Yerevan. Almost everyone will stop, but there are almost no cars and the lifts are short.
Lots of traffic and easy for cars to see you but difficult to get cars going where you want to (in my case Gyumri)

As of today, they say that hitchhikers can only go to Meghri and Agarak. They can't go to Tsav and come back. If you like to speak with locals or fellow travelers then you can find a ride from Agarak to Tsav or Nrnadzor. I did not and i trust situation will change.

Overwhelming city, lots of attentions, people willing to interact and help. 2 different aged groups of men wanted to give me money within one hour, a man in the cultural center next to "No problem hotel" drove me to Soran park when i asked for camping spot. English speaking girl at the café over there gave me cheese at 10pm. Chinari monastery was not allowed me to climb from the village bus stop. 
Hitchhiking in from Chambarak was fun and easy (last man gifted a Holy Bible), hitchhiking out was
